segment.source: Develop your app to support the layouts and fonts of multiple languages, including RTL (right-to-left) flow direction.
segment.target: Develop your app to support the layouts and fonts of multiple languages, including RTL (right-to-left) flow direction.

segment.source: Adjust layout and fonts, and support RTL
segment.target: Adjust layout and fonts, and support RTL

segment.source: Adjust layout and fonts, and support RTL
segment.target: Adjust layout and fonts, and support RTL

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Develop your app to support the layouts and fonts of multiple languages, including RTL (right-to-left) flow direction.
segment.target: Develop your app to support the layouts and fonts of multiple languages, including RTL (right-to-left) flow direction.

segment.source: Layout guidelines
segment.target: Layout guidelines

segment.source: Some languages, such as German and Finnish, require more space than English for their text.
segment.target: Some languages, such as German and Finnish, require more space than English for their text.

segment.source: The fonts for some languages, such as Japanese, require more height.
segment.target: The fonts for some languages, such as Japanese, require more height.

segment.source: And some languages, such as Arabic and Hebrew, require that text layout and app layout must be in right-to-left (RTL) reading order.
segment.target: And some languages, such as Arabic and Hebrew, require that text layout and app layout must be in right-to-left (RTL) reading order.

segment.source: Use flexible layout mechanisms instead of absolute positioning, fixed widths, or fixed heights.
segment.target: Use flexible layout mechanisms instead of absolute positioning, fixed widths, or fixed heights.

segment.source: When necessary, particular UI elements can be adjusted based on language.
segment.target: When necessary, particular UI elements can be adjusted based on language.

segment.source: XAML
segment.target: XAML

segment.source: Specify a Uid for an element:
segment.target: Specify a Uid for an element:

segment.source: Ensure that your app's ResW file has a resource for Block1.Width, which you can set for each language that you localize into.
segment.target: Ensure that your app's ResW file has a resource for Block1.Width, which you can set for each language that you localize into.

segment.source: For Windows Store apps using C++, C#, or Visual Basic, use the FlowDirection property, with symmetrical padding and margins, to enable localization for other layout directions.
segment.target: For Windows Store apps using C++, C#, or Visual Basic, use the FlowDirection property, with symmetrical padding and margins, to enable localization for other layout directions.

segment.source: XAML layout controls such as Grid scale and flip automatically with the FlowDirection property.
segment.target: XAML layout controls such as Grid scale and flip automatically with the FlowDirection property.

segment.source: Expose your own FlowDirection property in your app as a resource for localizers.
segment.target: Expose your own FlowDirection property in your app as a resource for localizers.

segment.source: Specify a Uid for the main page of your app:
segment.target: Specify a Uid for the main page of your app:

segment.source: Ensure that your app's ResW file has a resource for MainPage.FlowDirection, which you can set for each language that you localize into.
segment.target: Ensure that your app's ResW file has a resource for MainPage.FlowDirection, which you can set for each language that you localize into.

segment.source: HTML
segment.target: HTML

segment.source: For Windows Store apps using JavaScript, use Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) layout mechanisms such as -ms-grid and –ms-box.
segment.target: For Windows Store apps using JavaScript, use Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) layout mechanisms such as -ms-grid and –ms-box.

segment.source: Use symmetrical padding and margins to enable localization for various layout directions.
segment.target: Use symmetrical padding and margins to enable localization for various layout directions.

segment.source: Your app can also use the :-ms-lang() pseudo-class selector to adjust CSS properties such as width on particular elements based on the language of the app.
segment.target: Your app can also use the :-ms-lang() pseudo-class selector to adjust CSS properties such as width on particular elements based on the language of the app.

segment.source: To enable this, the App Host sets the root element's lang attribute to the app language.
segment.target: To enable this, the App Host sets the root element's lang attribute to the app language.

segment.source: CSS
segment.target: CSS

segment.source: Windows Store apps using JavaScript that use the ui-light.css or ui-dark.css style sheets have their body layout direction set automatically, based on the app language.
segment.target: Windows Store apps using JavaScript that use the ui-light.css or ui-dark.css style sheets have their body layout direction set automatically, based on the app language.

segment.source: The following CSS is in ui-light and ui-dark.css, and you don't need to write it yourself.
segment.target: The following CSS is in ui-light and ui-dark.css, and you don't need to write it yourself.

segment.source: CSS
segment.target: CSS

segment.source: This means that most app layouts are set correctly when the system uses a right-to-left language.
segment.target: This means that most app layouts are set correctly when the system uses a right-to-left language.

segment.source: Like WinJS.UI controls, your app can use the :-ms-lang() pseudo-class selector to adjust physical CSS properties, such as margin and padding.
segment.target: Like WinJS.UI controls, your app can use the :-ms-lang() pseudo-class selector to adjust physical CSS properties, such as margin and padding.

segment.source: You don't need to adjust logical CSS properties that use keywords such as after and before.
segment.target: You don't need to adjust logical CSS properties that use keywords such as after and before.

segment.source: Don't use the align property or attribute in HTML.
segment.target: Don't use the align property or attribute in HTML.

segment.source: Instead, use the direction property to control alignment of particular components.
segment.target: Instead, use the direction property to control alignment of particular components.

segment.source: Use the writing-mode property to support vertical text layouts in CSS.
segment.target: Use the writing-mode property to support vertical text layouts in CSS.

segment.source: Mirroring images
segment.target: Mirroring images

segment.source: XAML
segment.target: XAML

segment.source: If your app has images that must be mirrored (that is, the same image can be flipped) for RTL, you can apply the FlowDirection property:
segment.target: If your app has images that must be mirrored (that is, the same image can be flipped) for RTL, you can apply the FlowDirection property:

segment.source: HTML
segment.target: HTML

segment.source: If your app has images that must be mirrored (that is, the same image can be flipped) for RTL, you can use CSS transforms to mirror your images at rendering time by adding a .mirrorable class to your elements and adding the following CSS class:
segment.target: If your app has images that must be mirrored (that is, the same image can be flipped) for RTL, you can use CSS transforms to mirror your images at rendering time by adding a .mirrorable class to your elements and adding the following CSS class:

segment.source: For both XAML and HTML: If your app requires a different image to flip the image correctly, you can use the resource management system with the layoutdir qualifier.
segment.target: For both XAML and HTML: If your app requires a different image to flip the image correctly, you can use the resource management system with the layoutdir qualifier.

segment.source: The system chooses an image named file.layoutdir-rtl.png when the application language is set to an RTL language.
segment.target: The system chooses an image named file.layoutdir-rtl.png when the application language is set to an RTL language.

segment.source: This approach may be necessary when some part of the image is flipped, but another part isn't.
segment.target: This approach may be necessary when some part of the image is flipped, but another part isn't.

segment.source: Fonts
segment.target: Fonts

segment.source: For both XAML and HTML: Use the LanguageFont font-mapping APIs for programmatic access to the recommended font family, size, weight, and style for a particular language.
segment.target: For both XAML and HTML: Use the LanguageFont font-mapping APIs for programmatic access to the recommended font family, size, weight, and style for a particular language.

segment.source: The LanguageFont object provides access to the correct font info for various categories of content including UI headers, notifications, body text, and user-editable document body fonts.
segment.target: The LanguageFont object provides access to the correct font info for various categories of content including UI headers, notifications, body text, and user-editable document body fonts.

segment.source: HTML
segment.target: HTML

segment.source: Windows Store apps using JavaScript that use the ui-light.css or ui-dark.css style sheets have their font set automatically to the most appropriate font, based on the app language.
segment.target: Windows Store apps using JavaScript that use the ui-light.css or ui-dark.css style sheets have their font set automatically to the most appropriate font, based on the app language.

segment.source: The App Host sets the root element's lang attribute to the app language.
segment.target: The App Host sets the root element's lang attribute to the app language.

segment.source: Apps that display multiple languages on a single page should set the lang attribute for the section in each language.
segment.target: Apps that display multiple languages on a single page should set the lang attribute for the section in each language.

segment.source: The :-ms-lang() pseudo-class selector picks up the correct font for each section of the page.
segment.target: The :-ms-lang() pseudo-class selector picks up the correct font for each section of the page.
